resources.string: Face is front of the head, use for five senses; communicating emotions
Scalp is top of the head (under hair), for cooling the head with sweat glands in the skin; protecting the skull with extra blood vessels
Forehead is top of the face, above the eyes, for forming facial expressions; protecting the eyes
Mouth is below the nose, for eating; talking; breathing; sense of taste
Eyes is below the forehead, above the nose, use for sense of sight
Eyelid is just above the eye, protecting the eyes from foreign particles; enable eyes to close
Eyelash is on the edges of the eyelid, protecting the eyes from foreign particles
Jaw is on top of the mouth (maxilla) and bottom of the mouth (mandible) , chewing; opening and closing the mouth; talking
Upper arm is between shoulders and elbows, flexing the arm; connecting the lower arm to the shoulder
Forearm is between elbows and wrists, flexing the wrist; connecting the arm to the wrist
Fingernail is end of finger, protecting nail beds from foreign particles; helping with grip
Shin is lower leg, under the knee, flexing the foot; stabilizing the ankle
Ankle is joint between the foot and shin, rotating the foot; connecting the foot to the leg
Heel is back of the foot, distributing body weight
Torso is middle of the body, between the neck and legs, stabilizing the body (posture); protecting internal organs; connecting the limbs (arms and legs) to the body
Abdomen is middle of the torso, stabilizing the body; protecting internal organs
Belly Button is the middle of the belly, connects a baby’s umbilical cord to its mother’s placenta before birth
Buttock is back of the torso, just above the legs, cushioning the body when sitting; assisting in hip and thigh movement
Arm is a human upper limb especially the part between the shoulder and the wrist. something like or corresponding to an arm. such as the forelimb of a vertebrate.
Ear is on either side of the head, sense of hearing; maintaining balance
Elbow is joint between the upper arm and forearm, connecting the upper arm to the forearm; extending the arm; rotating the lower arm
The foot is an anatomical structure found in many vertebrates. It is the terminal portion of a limb which bears weight and allows locomotion.
Wrist is the part of the body between hand and arm which bends when you move your hand.
Hips are the two areas at the sides of your body between the tops of your legs and your waist.
Knuckle is the joint between hand bones (carpals) and finger bones (phalanges) connecting the fingers to the hand; allow fingers to bend and extend
Middle finger commonly referred to as the long or tall finger sits in the center of the hand.
Palm is flat side of hand, helping with grip; sense of touch
Picky finger is the fifth digit and smallest of the fingers.

The index finger is the second digit of the hand. Along with the thumb and middle finger, it is one of the most often-used digits. This finger has practical applications of both sensory touch and grasp, but it is often used for expressive purposes as well. This usually takes the form of non-verbal hand gestures. For this reason, the index finger is also known as ‘the pointer’.
The ring finger refers to the fourth digit of each hand, located between the middle and pinky fingers.

Tooth, plural teeth, any of the hard, resistant structures occurring on the jaws and in or around the mouth and pharynx areas of vertebrates. Teeth are used for catching and masticating food, for defense, and for other specialized purposes.

the short thick digit of the human hand that is analogous in position to the big toe and differs from the other fingers in having only two phalanges, allowing greater freedom of movement, and being opposable to each of them also, Different from the other four digits in that it is shorter and wider and only has two phalanges instead of three, the thumb earned its name from a description of its physical characteristics in relation to its neighbors.
Hair is on top of the scalp, regulating body temperature; protecting the scalp

The human head is home to all the body\'s major sensory organs, and the most important of these is the brain. Although the nose, ears, tongue, nerves, and others parts are important, without a healthy brain, they\'d all be useless. Encased in the skull, the brain is the body\'s centralized conveyor of all information.
Neck is below the head, above the shoulders, for supporting the head’s weight; allowing the head to turn; sending messages from the brain to the rest of the body (vertebrae)
Chest is top of the torso, protecting lungs and heart; assisting in arm movement

The shoulder is one of the largest and most complex joints in the body. The shoulder joint is formed where the humerus (upper arm bone) fits into the scapula (shoulder blade), like a ball and socket. Other important bones in the shoulder include: The acromion is a bony projection off the scapula.

The wrist connects the hand to the forearm. It consists of the distal ends of the radius and ulna bones, eight carpal bones, and the proximal ends of five metacarpal bones. This arrangement of bones allows for a wide range of movement. The wrist can bend, straighten, move laterally, and rotate.
hand is end of the arm, connected to the wrist, fine motor skills (writing, pinching, gripping)
finger is end of hand, helping with grip; sense of touch; gesturing (pointing, hand signals, etc.)
Thigh is top of leg, above the knee, allowing the leg to flex and move; supporting weight of the upper body
Knee is joint between the thigh and shin, bending the leg; supporting weight of the upper body
Legs are below torso, above foot, keeping the body stable; walking; running; bending the body
Toe is end of the foot, providing balance while walking; distributing body weight

DEVELOPMENT OF AN ANDROID BASED MULTILINGUAL HUMAN BODY ORGAN TUTORING SYSTEM
